story: Share this article Earlier this week it was revealed that furlough and other business support accounted for half of Government spending on the coronavirus pandemic.  The National Audit Office (NAO) said the estimated cost of the Government's response to the coronavirus pandemic has risen to an 'eye-watering' £372 billion.That was up by more than £100 billion since its last report in January this year. The NAO Covid-19 cost tracker now captures a full year of predicted costs since the pandemic began, with £172 billion already spent.It includes £26 billion worth of guaranteed loans which are expected to be written off.Support for businesses such as the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme and the Bounce Back Loan Scheme had the highest estimated cost, at £151 billion.This was followed by help for the health and social care sector at £97 billion.

title: Andy Burnham says London North different West East Germany
story: Share this article 'Like many things wrong with this country, our problems today can be traced back to the Eighties. Back then, Margaret Thatcher decided to break up municipal bus companies everywhere across England, except London. 'We have had 35 years of rising fares, routes being cut and passenger numbers falling. We have barely any night buses, no Oyster system and no daily cap.'I mention it to help people understand why the North feels the way it does and, hopefully, win some support for our calls. A single bus journey in Harpurhey, Greater Manchester, should cost the same as one in Haringey, London — ie £1.55, not £4 plus. Is that so unreasonable? I don’t think so. Levelling up should mean London-style transport for all English city regions.'If London got behind that, it would reflect well on it and reduce anti-London feeling.'Mr Burnham's acceptance of a column in a newspaper whose readership is 200 miles from his political base in the North West comes as he admits he would like to lead Labour after Keir Starmer. But he also singled out for praise a potential rival, London mayor Sadiq Khan, saying he should be given additional powers to put him on a par with his counterparts in New York and Paris.Mr Khan himself raised eyebrows yesterday when he visited a factory in Yorkshire.The Mayor of London visited an electric bus factory in North Yorkshire, which manufactures state-of-the-art vehicles for London's 500-strong zero-emission fleet. At the weekend Mr Burnham claimed Labour would have held on to more northern seats at the  2019 election if he had been party leader instead of Jeremy Corbyn.The Greater Manchester mayor made the claim as he revealed he would run for the leadership again after the next election if he had enough support.Mr Burnham, a former health secretary under Gordon Brown, came a distant second to hard Left icon Mr Corbyn in the 2015 Labour leadership election, polling just 19 per cent of votes.He served as a shadow minister before quitting national politics to become mayor of Manchester before Labour's catastrophic display at the 2019 election, its worst since the 1930s.But buoyed by an increased majority in Manchester in the election last week, and Keir Starmer's increasing difficulty over Labour's wider results, Mr Burnham has learned towards a new run at the party leadership.Speaking to the Observer he was deeply critical of modern Labour's failure to take a stronger stance on major policy issues, particularly social care reform, and said the party lacked the boldness to attempt any move on the scale of its greatest achievement - creating the NHS in 1948.Mr Burnham said had he beaten Mr Corbyn to the leadership six years ago he would have been more successful in stopping the Conservatives from breaking the so-called 'red wall' - including the many northern heartland seats lost in the 2019 general election, and the crushing defeat endured in this month's Hartlepool by-election.'I still think life would have been different if I had won,' said Mr Burnham, who romped to victory in his mayoral election on May 6, taking all 215 wards in Greater Manchester.'I think we would be stronger in taking on the Government. I don't think we'd have lost as many northern seats had I won.'An Opinium poll published in the paper shows Mr Burnham - who also failed in a 2010 leadership bid - is widely seen as the most likely and able successor to current leader Sir Keir Starmer, with 47 per cent ranking him on top, ahead of 35 per cent for London mayor Sadiq Khan and 29 per cent for Leeds Central MP and former Labour frontbencher Hilary Benn.Andy Burnham: The Government wants to ide us but together we are a powerful force | Evening Standard

title: what if flying reduced your carbon footprint
story: Wind power pioneer Henrik Stiesdal is developing an aviation fuel from agricultural waste and green hydrogen that actually removes carbon from the atmosphere.Imagine a scenario where flying on planes reduced your carbon footprint. Wind power pioneer Henrik Stiesdal is developing an aviation fuel from agricultural waste and green hydrogen that actually removes carbon from the atmosphere.He told the Dublin Climate Dialogues conference that his new SkyClean fuel is produced by burning agricultural waste in a pyrolysis oven and combining some of the components with green hydrogen to create biomethanol, which can then be synthesised into aviation fuel.The end product is a fuel that is chemically the same to the A-1 jet fuel currently used by airlines but produced in a way that removes carbon from the atmosphere, which means its carbon negative.Trips“You could completely decarbonise aviation – there’s enough agricultural waste in the world to fuel aircraft several times over,” Mr Stiesdal said.“So you could say, be a good citizen, take some more holiday trips to Thailand, ” he saidThe technology is on track to be commercialised by 2025 and promises to be the most climate-friendly option to clean up the aviation industry, which is viewed as one of the hardest to decarbonise. It could also lead to an expansion in aviation, Mr Stiesdal said.The former chief technology officer at Siemens Wind Power told the conference that wind and solar were the only renewables with scale needed to quickly move away from fossil fuels.Mr Stiesdal also spoke about the gap between government pledges on climate and their actions.TargetsHe said a legal case taken in Germany, which found the government’s climate change laws were insufficient and violated fundamental freedoms by putting the burden of curbing emissions on the young was a template that’s likely to be used by activists more and more. Germany’s Constitutional Court ruled in April that the country’s 2019 climate protection act is in part unconstitutional.“The regulations irreversibly postpone high emission reduction burdens until periods after 2030,” the court said, while adding that the the law did not explain in enough detail how greenhouse gas emissions are to be reduced after 2031.The judges gave the government until the end of next year to draw up clearer reduction targets.

title: covid 19 vaccine tracker what s available in the republic of ireland and what else is coming
story: It has been over a year since the first case of Covid-19 was confirmed in the Republic of Ireland. Since then, over 250,000 people have been diagnosed in the State, and more than 4,900 people have died.Globally, over 150 million people have been diagnosed and over 3&nbspmillion have died since the virus was first identified in China in December 2019.Four of these have been authorised for use in the EU - one from AstraZeneca, one from BioNTech-Pfizer, one from Moderna and another from Johnson &amp Johnson (Jannsen).The EU has put in place purchase agreements with Sanofi-GSK&nbspand Curevac, and&nbsphas concluded exploratory talks with two other vaccine producers - Novavax and Valneva.Ireland, along with all other EU member states, will get a proportional amount of every vaccine that is approved for use by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) according to its population.But how do these other vaccines work, and when will they be approved for use here? Have there been any reported side effects? And when can you expect to receive a vaccine?The  Vaccine Tracker will be updated daily as the country embarks on the largest inoculation programme in the history of the State.Storage: Must be kept in a freezer at - 70°C.EMA approval: Granted on December 21st.Overview: Developed by New York-based Pfizer and German company BioNTech this vaccine has a brand name of Comirnaty. It uses messenger RNA (mRNA) technology, which has instructions for producing a protein from Sars-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19. The person’s immune system recognises this protein as foreign and produces antibodies and activates T-cells (white blood cells) to attack it, giving them immunity. The vaccine will last for six months when stored at -70C, and five days when stored at between 2 and 8 degrees Celsius. The EU has approved the withdrawal of six doses from each vial.Side effects: Common side effects (occurring in more than 1 in 10 people) included pain and swelling at the injection site, tiredness, headache, muscle and joint pain, chills and fever. Severe allergic reactions occurred in a very small number of cases.How many will Ireland get? 546,000 in April, 738,000 in May and&nbsp844,000 doses in June, with 5.4 million doses in total expected by the end of 2021.Storage: Must be kept in a freezer at - 20°C.EMA approval: Granted on January 6th.Overview: Developed by Boston-based company Moderna, this vaccine is manufactured for EU states at partner plants in Switzerland, France and Spain before being distributed across the continent. Like the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine, it uses mRNA technology to produce a Sars-CoV-2 protein, which the body then attacks to give immunity. It will last for up to six months when stored at - 20°C. The first Moderna vaccine was given in Ireland on January 16th.Side effects: Common side effects (occurring in more than 1 in 10 people) included pain and swelling at the injection site, tiredness, chills, fever, swollen or tender lymph nodes under the arm, headache, muscle and joint pain, nausea and vomiting. Less common was redness, hives and rash at the injection site. Severe allergic reactions occurred in a very small number of cases.How many will Ireland get? 383,000 by June and 870,000 doses by the end of 2021.How many have been vaccinated here?EMA approval: Granted on January 29th.Overview: The OxfordAstraZeneca vaccine (also known as Vaxzevria) was thought of as a potential game-changer because it can be transported and stored at 2 degrees to 8 degrees for up to six months, making it much easier to move around and administer. It is also much cheaper, costing about $3-4 per shot, compared with $20 for the PfizerBioNTech jab, with the former being made on a not-for-profit basis for the duration of the pandemic.It is based on a harmless chimp cold virus that cannot grow inside human cells. Scientists have tweaked this virus so that it carries genetic material containing the instructions for a protein of the coronavirus. Once the vaccine has been administered, our bodies produce the coronavirus protein, triggering an immune response.During the trial, a dosing error led to the serendipitous finding that when clinical trial participants were given half a dose followed by a full dose, the vaccine had a higher efficacy than when participants were given two full doses, with 90 per cent efficacy in the former case and 62 per cent efficacy in the latter. This led AstraZeneca to announce in November a new global trial of the vaccine with the half dosefull dose regime.In January, a bitter row broke out between the European Union and AstraZeneca after the pharmaceutical company drastically revised downwards the number of doses it could deliver the bloc.&nbspWhile the EMA approved the use of this vaccine for all ages, doubt was cast over its efficacy in the over 65s due to the lack of data from Astrazeneca’s clinical trials in this cohort. As a result, Germany, Austria, Sweden, Poland and Belgium have opted not to approve this product for their older population.Following suit, Ireland has also decided to use the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine for the over 70s where possible, not the AstraZeneca jab.It would not be the first time this jab led to a&nbspsignificant reorganisation of our vaccination plans.Reports of serious blood clots, mostly in women aged under 60, led the&nbspNational Immunisation Advisory Committee (Niac) to first defer the use of the vaccine on March 14th, before resuming it's use on March 20th.However, on April 12th, Niac&nbsprecommended that AstraZeneca should not be given to people aged under 60, once again leading to a reorganisation of the rollout. This was revised to people aged over 50 on April 27th.&nbspHow many will Ireland get?&nbspLatest projections are 224,000 in April, 262,000 in May and 327,000 in JuneStorage: Lasts for up to two years frozen at –20° C, and up to three months refrigerated at 2–8° C.EMA approval: Approved on March 11th.Overview: The EMA started a rolling review of this single dose vaccine from Janssen, the Belgium-based subsidiary of Johnson &amp Johnson on December 1st .On January 29th the company announced the results of its Phase 3 trial: the vaccine had an efficacy of 72 per cent in the United States, 66 per cent in Latin America, and 57 per cent in South Africa.This vaccine uses double-stranded DNA to deliver a protein from the SARS-CoV-2 virus into the body, thereby creating immunity. It is different from others on the market in that it requires just one injection. The EU has agreed an initial contract for 200 million doses, with an option to buy 200 million more.On February 16th the company applied to the EMA for&nbspseeking authorisation for its single-dose vaccine, and it was approved on March 11th.However, on April 13th the company paused deliveries of its vaccine in Europe pending an investigation of rare blood clot cases that have halted its rollout in the US. The blood clotting conditions reported in recipients of the Johnson &amp Johnson vaccine in the US are the same rare condition linked to the AstraZeneca vaccine.On April 20th, the EMA's review of these issues found a possible link to very rare cases of unusual blood clots with low blood platelets, and agreed a warning should be included in the product information.&nbspHowever, it concluded&nbspthe overall benefits of the vaccine&nbspin preventing Covid-19 outweigh the risks of side effects, and so Janssen announced it would resume deliveries to the EU. In Ireland,&nbspNiac recommended that the jab be used only for people over the age of 50.How many will Ireland get?&nbsp2.2 million doses in total,&nbsp600,000 between April and June.Storage: Stable at 2°C to 8°C.Overview: US company Novavax has developed a Covid-19 vaccine which stimulates an immune response by delivering spike proteins into the body. These spike-proteins are grown and harvested from insects. Similar technology is used in the production of vaccines for influenza and HPV. The European Commission has concluded exploratory talks with Novavax with a view to purchasing up to 200 million doses. The EMA began a rolling review of the vaccine on February 3rd.Overview: In September the EU signed a deal to purchase 300 million doses of this vaccine. It is based on the same technology as one of Sanofi’s seasonal influenza vaccines - more conventional than the mRNA used by Pfizer and Moderna - and it was thought it could play a big role in ending the pandemic. However, despite positive results from Phase 1 trials, news came in December that Phase 2 trial results showed an insufficient immune response in older adults. Phase III studies were expected to start in December, but the companies now plan to begin a phase 2b study in February with a different formulation of the vaccine. Even if their new formulation is successful, they do not expect the vaccine to be available until the end of 2021.Storage: Will last for at least 3 months at 2–8°C.Overview: The German company CureVac began its final Phase 3 trials in December, with results expected in the first quarter of 2021. It uses the same mRNA technology as the Moderna and Pfizer vaccines, but can be kept at normal refrigerator temperatures. The company has signed a deal with the EU to supply 405 million doses, pending regulatory approval.The EMA began a rolling review of the vaccine on February 12th.Storage: Stable at 2°C to 8°C.Overview: Valneva is a French company which has created a Covid-19 vaccine based on their Japanese encephalitis vaccine. It delivers a chemically inactivated coronavirus and uses an adjuvant (immunity booster) to create immunity. It entered clinical trials in December and reported positive results from these initial phase 1 and 2 trial in&nbspApril 2021, while announcing it was entering&nbspphase 3 trials on 4,000 people.On January 12th the European Commission concluded exploratory talks with the company for the supply of 30 million doses, with the option to buy a further 30 million.When might you be vaccinated?The HSE is currently vaccinating people in the top nine cohorts:&nbsppeople aged 65&nbspand older who live in long-term care facilities (cohort 1), frontline healthcare workers (cohort 2), people aged 70 and older (cohort 3), people aged 16 to 69 who are at very high or high risk (cohort 4 and 7) and those aged 50 to 69 (cohorts 5 and 9).&nbspThe next groups to be offered a vaccine after this will be residents of long-term care facilities aged 16-64 (cohort 8), followed by people aged 64 years and younger, alongside people aged 64 and younger who are living or working in crowded settings. The programme will work down through the age groups, from eldest to youngest. To register for your vaccine, you can visit the HSE site here.Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreak

title: covid international travel may return before august coveney says
story: International travel may return before August, Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney has told a private Fine Gael meeting.Sources at Wednesday night’s parliamentary party meeting say Mr Coveney said estimates given by Leo Varadkar about international travel not returning until at least August could be seen as being conservative.Mr Coveney told TDs and Senators that “it may happen before then”. He said, however, that instead of over-promising and under delivering for the public on this, the Government should aim to do the opposite. He also said the Cabinet will bring significant clarity to the issue next week.Mr Coveney said that by the end of June the EU green pass process will be signed off on. Member states will have six weeks then to put this new travel scheme into operation.Super Junior Minister for International and Road Transport Hildegarde Naughton also told the meeting it would be “good news” if international travel could resume before August, but she cautioned it will take time before people feel comfortable flying again.The Cabinet will outline a roadmap for aviation and the resumption of international travel next week.The Government statement will also include plans for the future of mandatory hotel quarantine as well as sports and entertainment as part of the next phase of reopening for June and July.On Wednesday, EU member states agreed to ease Covid-19 travel restrictions on non-EU visitors ahead of the summer tourist season.EU countries approved a European Commission proposal to loosen the criteria to determine “safe” countries and to let in fully vaccinated tourists from elsewhere, EU sources said.They are expected to set a new list this week or early next week. Under the plan, EU countries would admit fully jabbed visitors from outside the bloc for non-essential travel, according to a copy of the proposals seen by the Financial Times.Visitors would need to have received their final dose of a vaccine approved by the European Medicines Agency – BioNTechPfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson &amp Johnson – at least 14 days before arrival in the EU.Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreak

title: minister says time is right to act on airbnb
story: Minister for Housing Darragh O’Brien said existing rules on holiday lets were ‘decent’ but that enforcement has been an issue. Photograph: Damien Eagers  The  Now is the time to further regulate short-term lettings such as Airbnb rentals before the resumption of international travel, the Minister for Housing Darragh O’Brien has said.Mr O’Brien confirmed comments he made privately to the Fine Gael parliamentary party that the Government intends to crackdown on Airbnb lettings that should not be advertising online.Under the new plans a property would not be allowed to advertise on the platform without the requisite planning permission.At present, iniduals renting out a home for more than 90 days or landlords letting out a second property to tourists or others on a short-term basis must apply for planning permission either on a new or retention basis. There has been criticism, however, that this is not adequately regulated or enforced and homes are still being advertised without permission.“Decent regulations were brought in in 2019 around the planning permission that would be required for any homes that are used for more than 90 days a year. The problem has been the enforcement of that frankly,” Mr O’Brien said in Dublin on Thursday.“What we are working on in conjunction with Minister Catherine Martin’s department is a mechanism whereby you would regulate the platforms. Effectively what that means is that somebody would not be able to advertise a short-term letting property unless they had received the requisite planning permission to do so.“Now is the time to do it particularly when we don’t have throngs of international visitors here. We have been working on this for some time. We have looked at other models in continental Europe in particular. Most capital cities in Europe have a stronger regulation than we have and I think we can do this in the short term.”“I hope to conclude that (work) by the end of the summer,” he added.Fine Gael senator Tim Lombard said that “Airbnb is effectively sucking the life out of rental markets in villages, towns and cities across the country, leaving local people locked out of accessing homes.”He said that an Airbnb property which is occupied for three months during the summer season can make “significantly more money than a property rented out for 12 months.”“However, by letting properties on a seasonal basis, large amounts of homes across the country are lying vacant for the vast majority of the year.“During a time when we’re facing a critical lack of supply of housing, we can’t afford to have perfectly good homes lying empty for over 50 per cent of the year. “While tourists might want to book a holiday home for a two-week break during the summer, local families are left struggling to find a home at a price they can afford.”Mr Lombard said that Kinsale has seen rental prices increase over the past few years due to lack of supply in the local property market.“At the same time, we’ve seen hundreds of houses become available on the Airbnb website for holiday use. The majority of these houses are in residential areas, and when they received planning permission it was on the basis that the properties would be for residential use only.”

title: closure of drive in cinema for alleged covid 19 breaches baffling
story: Minister to share his concerns with officials ‘to see whether we can do anything’. File photograph: GettyMinister for Communications Eamon Ryan has questioned how a drive-in movie business could be seen as a health risk for the spread of Covid-19 after Retro Drive-in Movies in Leopardstown, Dublin, was closed for alleged breaches of regulations.Mr Ryan will speak to Government colleagues “including officials dealing with the management of the public health crisis, to see whether anything can be done specifically in this instance”.He said it seemed “that drive-in movies would be as safe as we could get”. He and Minister for Arts Catherine Martin will have meetings next week about the reopening of the country and “she is very keen that cinemas and theatres will start to reopen in a safe way”. The Minister was responding to Fine Gael TD Neale Richmond who described the closure as “absolutely baffling”. The Dublin Rathdown TD said he had attended the drive-in cinemas last Friday and the closure was a surprise to the business itself as well as to customers.Mr Richmond said the closure of the cinema “makes absolutely no sense” when people can go to non-essential retail and the zoo, travel intercounty and visit people in gardens they cannot drive and watch a film from the safety of their car.He said that under statutory instrument or regulation 219 of 2021 Health Act 1947, “cinemas were listed as not permitted but drive-in cinemas were listed as an exception”.The Minister assured him he would share his concerns with officials “to see whether we can do anything”.

title: dogs can better detect covid in humans than lateral flow tests study
story: ‘Results are scientific confirmation of dogs’ capacity to detect the olfactory signature of Covid-19,’ according to Paris hospital board. Dogs are better at detecting coronavirus in humans than many fast lateral flow tests (LFTs), according to a French study which could mean canines are more widely deployed for mass virus screening in crowded places including airports.The trial, conducted in March and April by France’s national veterinary school and the clinical research unit of Paris’s Necker-Cochin hospital, showed dogs were able to detect the presence of the virus with 97 per cent accuracy.The dogs were also 91 per cent correct in identifying negative samples, the study showed. A recent review of 64 studies found LFTs correctly identify on average 72 per cent of people infected with the virus who have symptoms, and 58 per cent who do not.“These results are scientific confirmation of dogs’ capacity to detect the olfactory signature of Covid-19,” the Paris hospital board said, adding that the study - which is due to be published in a scientific review - was the first of its kind.“These are excellent results, comparable with those of a PCR test,” Prof Jean-Marc Treluyer told Agence-France Presse. He said dogs would not replace polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests, which are significantly more reliable than LFT tests.But, he said, “they could help identify those people who should undergo a full viral test and – because the dogs’ response is so quick – facilitate mass testing” in places such as airports, train stations and concert venues.In the French study, researchers collected samples – cotton pads pressed for two minutes under participants’ armpits – from 335 people aged between six and 76 who presented themselves for a PCR test at testing centres in Paris.The pads were then sealed in jars and given to at least two of the nine dogs used in the trial – none of whom came into contact with the volunteers – to be sniffed. The dogs’ handlers did not know in advance which samples were positive.The dogs detected 97 per cent of the 109 people whose PCR test subsequently proved positive, and 91 per cent of those whose PCR test was negative.Researchers in countries including Australia, Germany and Britain have experimented with dogs to detect coronavirus, while Finland and the United Arab Emirates last year launched trials with sniffer dogs at Helsinki and Dubai international airports. – Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreakStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: fiona bruce questioned bbc chairmans praise womanising genius
story: The chairman of the BBC was taken to task by Fiona Bruce after holding up a famously sexist US physicist as the epitome of genius.Richard Sharp’s praise for Richard Feynman, the late Nobel Laureate, raised eyebrows during a BBC event.Mr Sharp was taking part in an online Q&ampA with staff, hosted by Bruce, when he spoke approvingly of Feynman’s achievements while acknowledging that he was a womaniser.Bruce, the Question Time host, responded by asking if Mr Sharp was advocating the womanising aspect of Feynman’s character. Mr Sharp assured her that he was not.In his memoir, Surely You’re Joking, Mr Feynman!, the physicist detailed the womanising ways of his youth and set out his early technique of seducing “worthless bitches”.An amateur artist, he produced a portrait of “a beautiful blonde woman” during a life drawing class and named it after Marie Curie, saying: “Nobody thinks of Madame Curie as a woman, as feminine, with beautiful hair, bare breasts and all that. They only think of the radium part.”Mr Sharp brought up Feynman’s name when a staff member taking part in the Q&ampA asked him how he would define genius. The chairman directed staff to watch a 1981 BBC Horizon documentary, The Pleasure of Finding Things Out.Feynman, who died in 1988, was regarded in his day as a great wit and brilliant mind. He was a member of the team that developed the first atomic bomb at Los Alamos and taught at the California Institute of Technology.In 1986, sitting on the Presidential Commission into the Challenger space shuttle disaster, he conducted an impromptu experiment during a committee hearing that succinctly explained how the accident had occurred.A BBC spokesperson said: “At an internal staff event, the chairman was asked about how to measure genius. He responded by talking about the incredible talent within the BBC and recommended that staff watch the Richard Feynman Horizon interviews.“Describing someone as a genius is simply that - it’s not an endorsement of everything they may have said and done.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: knee jerk lockdowns not answer
story: Figures from the Office for National Statistics show that deaths from Covid currently make up less than two per cent of all weekly fatalities. Yet despite the retreat of the pandemic in the face of a remarkably successful vaccination programme, the fear of a Covid upsurge continues to dominate debate around public health almost to the exclusion of all other considerations.The Prime Minister, who had been confident until recently that the “road map” to normality was on track, is now hedging his bets. Arguably the pace of the unlocking was already too cautious given the rapid decline in hospitalisations and fatalities – supposedly the two key metrics for deciding on the next steps.Where is any cost-benefit analysis of keeping these restrictions in place? Governments may legitimately take draconian action in the midst of a rapidly accelerating epidemic but it is unacceptable to continue with these constraints when the impact of the virus is both low and localised. Those who say the measures are justified in order to limit the risk of future infections need to ask themselves when this would end.Contingency plans that had been drawn up for dealing with pandemics were largely abandoned when the coronavirus hit. Lockdowns spread around the world from China and then Italy as hospitals came under massive pressure in some areas. But no one had ever carried out an assessment of the effect lockdowns would have on society beyond the public health benefit occasioned by keeping people apart.Fear of being blamed is at the heart of this. Dominic Cummings, the former No 10 aide, is promising to make startling revelations about what was done in the early stages of the pandemic when he appears before a select committee next week. As Clement Attlee once said of Harold Laski, a period of silence on his part would be welcome.Even though the most vulnerable people have been vaccinated, the Government’s concern appears to be the potential spread of a more virulent strain of Covid among the unvaccinated population, placing pressure once again on hospitals. But this should be addressed either by increasing capacity or developing triage procedures that allow people to be treated away from hospital.Moreover, why are the rules governing face coverings not being withdrawn? In America, where Covid rates are higher than here, Joe Biden has effectively bowed to the action already being taken by many US states and removed the requirement for vaccinated people to wear masks. Here, it is startling to see so few MPs in the Commons chamber, and for those who are there all to be masked, at a time when offices up and down the land are trying to get their employees to return to their desks. Vaccinated MPs who recently went into the chamber without a mask were upbraided by the Speaker who threatened to suspend the sitting. What example are our elected representatives setting? They are just projecting fear. If people want to carry on wearing masks, let them – but to insist that those who have been fully vaccinated must do so is perverse.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: labour politicians oppose immigration enforcement have given
story: Perhaps a previously under-discussed reason that Labour isn’t being taken seriously as a potential government is staring us in the face: far too many Labour politicians don’t take the prospect seriously themselves.Earlier this week, Dr Rosena Allin-Khan, the shadow secretary of state for mental health (yet another shadow cabinet position distinguished by the fact that its occupant doesn’t shadow an actual cabinet minister), tweeted her unhappiness about a police operation that uncovered a couple of iniduals suspected of “migration offences”.She may have had a genuine grievance: why were immigration officers attending a police operation ostensibly aimed at clamping down on those who flout covid restrictions? As she commented later, “This looks like racial profiling”. But Dr Allin-Khan is a member of Keir Starmer’s front bench team. With Labour in the midst of an identity crisis, with traditional Labour voters (many of whom happen to believe immigration should be tightly regulated) looking sceptically at what Labour has to offer, she comes across – perhaps unfairly – as being sceptical of the merit of enforcing immigration law.Meanwhile in Scotland in the past week, Scottish Labour have been busy giving their support to any illegal immigrant who fancies staying put and ignoring immigration law. An attempt to remove two of them physically last week “disgusted” the party’s leader, Anas Sarwar, while one of his newly elected MSPs, Paul Sweeney, a former MP, endorsed the “civil disobedience” of the crowd of Glaswegians who forced police to release the two men who had chosen to stay here illegally after their visas expired.It should be pointed out that for those at whom these various expressions of solidarity were aimed will have welcomed them. Rather optimistically, Sweeney went on to say that the forced removal of migrants was opposed by a “majority” of Scots, but even dismissing this as wishful thinking on his part, there is a section of society only too happy to be told that they should stand up to The Man and that they should always get their own way, irrespective of the law.It’s when we dig deeper into these politicians’ roles that we start to unearth some serious questions and concerns. In the event of a Labour victory at the next general election, Dr Allin-Khan can expect to become a minister. At which point she will be bound by government collective responsibility. Since it is beyond unlikely that a government of any party could win the support of the electorate while insisting that all illegal immigrants can stay and work in the country whose laws they have spent years disrespecting, we must assume that the next Labour government, like all previous Labour governments, will be committed to enforcing immigration laws.It is as well that Dr Allin-Khan’s tenure as an MP has occurred during a period when elevation to government is only a remote prospect I doubt if she and many of her colleagues would have been comfortable as Labour MPs when her party was in government, when immigration detention centres were in full vigour and the party’s MPs – back benchers as well as ministers – regularly had to defend ministerial decisions that meant sending thousands of people back to their countries of origin against their will.Sarwar and Sweeney’s situation is doubtless a bit easier: MSPs have no responsibility whatsoever for immigration policy and are free to behave like student politicians if they wish, saying whatever their audience wants to hear and basking in their approval, if not their votes. Similarly, Scottish Labour’s self-indulgent decision to oppose Trident nuclear missiles was a popular position to take given that it’s MPs, not MSPs, who make defence decisions.Whatever the differences in political responsibilities, however, it is the common culture and attitude to difficult policy areas that still unite the disparate parts of the Labour Party. Both Scottish Labour and UK Labour have spent so long out of government that few, if any, of their respective front benches have any ministerial experience. They’ve chosen to forget the inconvenient truth that being in government sometimes means having to stand up in front of hostile crowds and tell them they are wrong and the government is right. And then they have to vote for unpopular things in the Commons.Opposition does that to politicians they stop seeing themselves as potential governors and start seeing themselves instead as mere ciphers for whoever in their communities have the loudest voices. That makes life a lot easier.And right there is the problem: too many of our elected opposition politicians want an easy life, where everyone likes them and everyone agrees with them. And the more distant becomes the prospect of one day getting into government, the more tempting it is to indulge the opinions of the last person who sat on you. And so a vicious cycle begins: no prospect of government means MPs feel free to indulge in more populist commentary, while more populist statements make the prospect of winning an election ever less likely. And so on.The tactic feels like it’s working because that comfortable echo chamber seems to like what you say. But then, come election night, you’re reminded that other people, the sort who don’t necessarily come along to town hall meetings or use social media, also have a vote. And when reality bites you have a choice: either be seen as a serious politician with serious, uncomfortable truths to impart, or carry on as you were, lapping up the approval of a tiny percentage of the electorate.The choice seems to have been made already by too many in Labour.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pandemic ending now zero excuse ignore economic woes
story: Something seems to have gone missing from the public discourse on Covid-19: money. True, in the depths of the first lockdown anyone who dared bring up the subject of the horrific cost of closing down the economy for weeks on end was quickly put down with meaningless platitudes like “life is too important for money” - as if money were just some abstract parlour game rather than a means by which limited resources can be allocated to healthcare and other competing needs. But at least we had some sort of debate. Now, the government tells us to cancel our summer holidays and suggests it might delay the planned 21 June lifting of most Covid restrictions – and hardly anyone dares even mention the cost in jobs and extra public debt.In a few off-the-cuff comments ministers have just condemned the tourism industry to a second lost season – an industry which until a few days ago was gearing itself for the lifting of a ban on foreign holidays. Outbound tourism, according to ABTA, is an industry worth £11.7 billion a year to the UK economy. Did that even enter Matt Hancock’s head when he said this week - contrary to what most people understood - that Britons should still consider themselves barred from amber-list countries unless they are on some desperate mission such as going to care for a dying relative?There was a time when the economy was central to everything the government did. Unemployment figures, trade figures, economic growth governments lived or died by such measures. Yet the current administration has redefined its role as one overwhelmingly concerned with one thing: keeping Covid infections low. As for the economy, it seems to take the attitude that it can look after itself – even when many economic activities have been banned by the state. As soon as restrictions are lifted, goes the thinking, we’ll have such a huge rebound that everything will be okay. The government’s resolve to ignore the economy was bolstered by the Bank of England upgrading its forecast for UK economic growth in 2021 from five per cent to 7.25 per cent.Yet, less noticed, the Bank simultaneously reduced its forecast for 2022 by a similar amount. Moreover, even if the economy does grow by 7.25 per cent this year it will still be smaller than it was at the beginning of February 2020. On 31 March we still had 4.2 million on furlough – or unemployed by another name. Many of these jobs will be gone for good, but we just don’t know it yet. The government is nursing a £303 billion deficit. Inflation has doubled in a month to 1.5 per cent as a wave of printed money runs up against a wall of reduced productive capacity. The latter poked its way into the headlines this week, but only briefly between scary government briefings over the Indian variant.    At the beginning of this year there was huge confidence that the government’s vaccination programme – for which it has rightly won plaudits – was going to give Britain a headstart in economic recovery. In Britain life would be back to normal while other countries were still battling outbreaks. But any advantage that we had has been thrown away by the government’s refusal to open up sooner. Denmark may have been delayed in its vaccination programme, which contributed to a blip in cases in March, yet still it is planning to lift most Covid restrictions on 8 June - two weeks ahead of Britain’s now-threatened full reopening.Yet just where is the Indian variant crisis? Whether it has greater transmissibility or not, the seven day average of Covid infections is actually down over the week - not that you would guess from the tone of government pronouncements, which give the impression of a new terror rampant in the land, so deadly that it has rendered the massive vaccination programme worthless.But hey, lives are more important than money. We’ll find out how true that is when we have several million unemployed, poverty is rising and our cancer wards start to fill up with people who could have been cured, but now cannot, thanks to their being too scared to seek treatment while the government is obsessed about new variants. As we will find out eventually, there is no hard choice between lives and money. The loss of the former is very often closely related to a lack of the latter.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: progressive democrats pressure joe biden get tough israel amid
story: US President Joe Biden is facing pressure from within his own party to take a tougher stance on Israel as progressive Democrats call for the cancellation of a $735 million arms deal amid ongoing fighting with Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip. Democratic Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Mark Pocan and Rashida Tlaib introduced a resolution Wednesday seeking to block American arms company Boeing selling precision-guided weapons to Israel, in a sale approved by the Biden administration earlier this month. The symbolic measure, which has at least six other co-sponsors including some of the most Left-leaning Democrats in the House, was unlikely to pass but signals Israel’s changing relationship with its most powerful ally, following four years of unconditional US support under former president Donald Trump. The harsh truth is that these weapons are being sold by the United States to Israel with the clear understanding that the vast majority of them will be used to bomb Gaza, added Ms Tlaib, who is of Palestinian origin.She was seen in deep conversation with Mr Biden on Tuesday afternoon, where she reportedly urged him to end US military support for Israel.  This new relationship appears to be reflected in changing public opinion, with a recent Gallup poll finding that 34 per cent of Americans support putting pressure on Israel, a new high. The resolution came after the president told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday to immediately wind down fighting with Hamas in the Gaza Strip, which has so far killed over 200 people. It came after days in which Mr Biden declined to call for a ceasefire.“The President conveyed to the Prime Minister that he expected a significant de-escalation today on the path to a cease-fire,” the White House said Wednesday in an account of Mr Biden’s fourth call with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the fighting erupted last Monday.It was the first time the president had publicly pressured the Israeli leader to implement a ceasefire and the three-sentence statement differed from previous readouts by omitting usual references to Israel’s right to defend itself and by giving a timeframe for action. Later White House spokeswoman Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters aboard Air Force One:  “The United States is working tirelessly through various levels of government to express support for a cease-fire, get to a place of sustainable calm, and build a path forward to addressing the underlying causes of conflict.”She added: “The two leaders had a detailed discussion on the state of events in Gaza, the Israelis progress in degrading the capabilities of Hamas and other terrorist elements, and ongoing diplomatic efforts by regional governments and the United States.”But Mr Biden’s statements are unlikely to satisfy the Left wing of his party, which has urged him to push harder to end the violence, in which thousands of militant rocket attacks on civilian areas of Israel have been met with air strikes that have killed dozens of Palestinian civilians.The sale of the Boeing Joint Direct Attack Munitions is likely to go ahead, with most Republicans and Democrats in Congress still supporting strong support for Israel, which is the largest beneficiary of US foreign aid, receiving some $3.8 billion a year.Republicans have accused Mr Biden of bowing to pressure within his party to abandon a longstanding ally. “Today he said he expects a significant de-escalation from Israel,” said Senator Tom Cotton. “What he needs to say is that he expects Iran and Hamas to stop terrorising the people of Israel.”Senator Jerry Moran said it is “shocking to me to see how much the administration has changed over time in regard to support for Israel.”  But the fact that the weapons sale was not even in question before the start of the fiercest fighting in years erupted last Monday suggests that Israel may be relying on qualified American support for the first time in years. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our The European Council today agreed to expand a “whitelist” of nations from which holidaymakers without both doses can travel. But there are still doubts over whether Britain will make it onto the list - despite passing one of the key tests to get on it. The Council agreed to raise the cut-off point for whitelist countries from  cases per , to  per ,. The UK’s rate is around  - low enough to make the cut.However, the Council has also added “iants of interest or concern” to the checklist before a country can be deemed safe. That could become a sticking point for the UK, where around , cases of the Indian iant have been found so far. The whitelist is expected be announced in the coming days and will be reviewed every two weeks. According to The Times, Britain could be held off the whitelist at first and only added when it is updated in two weeks’ time. An EU ambassador told the newspaper: “It makes sense to kick the can down the road to see the latest numbers and data to assess whether the surge has levelled off. The whitelist is separate to the EU’s plans to let in fully-vaccinated tourists no matter where they’re from, which were also approved by the Council today. Any changes risk adding even more confusion for Brits, thousands of whom are already planning holidays against UK advice. Most European countries are still on the UK’s “amber” own list - meaning Brits would have to quarantine when they get home, regardless of what rules apply in the EU. On top of this, inidual EU countries are able to decide their own rules on top of recommendations from the Council. For example, Portugal is allowing entry to unvaccinated Brits as long as they pass a health screening and go through Covid testing.  It comes as more than a quarter of a million passengers will fly from the UK to amber list countries by the weekend – despite ministersapos desperate pleas not to travel. It found more than , flights are scheduled to fly to amber list countries in the five days to Sunday at a rate of up to , passengers daily. Following days of mixed Government messages, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps urged sunseekers not to jet to amber countries. He told the BBC: The amber list and the red list are not for holidaymakers, thataposs not the purpose of those lists at this time. “We just think that after a year of lockdowns in this country, of people coming forward in record numbers to get their vaccines, we do not want to be in a position of taking risks at this stage about our unlock. An amber list country was not free and open travel and we ask people not to go to these places for holidays, he added. The Cabinet Minister begged Britons to wait longer before jetting off. Our message is very straightforward, which is, aposJust a little bit of patience, everyoneapos,”,he said. I know itaposs been an incredibly tough year and there are extreme circumstance where people will feel that it is the right thing to do – perhaps because they have a sick family member and some extreme situations where theyaposll travel in the orange category. “But by and large we are just asking people to be a little bit patient as other countries catch up with our world-leading vaccination programme and then people will be able to, I hope, travel.” He offered hope that more nations would be deemed safe for quarantine-free travel as the summer marched on.FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnThe TimesEuropean UnionBBCEuropean CouncilGrant Shapps

title: what great british railways shake
story: NewsWhat Great British Railways shake-up actually means for ticket prices and your walletThe Tories have finally started to unwind bits of disastrous privatisation - and put Grant Shapps in charge as a fat controller. But brush aside all the bluster and it wont actually mean cheap faresmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsWhat will Boris Johnsons shake-up mean for your wallet  The answer, it seems, is not very much " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Tories have finally unwound a major part of their failed privatisation agenda with the biggest rail shake-up for  years. A new body called Great British Railways will oversee both the track and the trains with ministers as the “fat controller” overhead. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps claims the major change will make the railways simpler and spend less on internal wrangling. It will end the current franchising model and instead pay operators with a string of controls on quality and running trains on time. But private companies will still be involved in running services even though they are badged with an updated version of the iconic “two arrows” logo. So what about the crucial question for passengers - what this reform will actually mean for ticket prices and your wallet   Despite finding fares have shot up % in real terms since , and only % of passengers think their journey is value for money, today’s -page report makes absolutely no promise to make tickets cheaper. There’s a lot of tinkering with the system to make it simpler - and therefore, you might argue, cheaper for those who’d been stung by expensive fares before. Next month there’ll also be a fares boost for part-time commuters. But overall, a lot of the eye-watering ticket prices we see on the network might end up staying the same. Dan Bloom runs through what the review promises - and what it doesn’t. What is the reform going to do  Until now, most rail services have been run by private firms awarded franchises by the Government.  The Williams-Shapps Plan for Railsets up a new public body called Great British Railways . It will take over responsibility for managing infrastructure, issuing contracts to train operators, setting fares and selling tickets. This is a much wider responsibility than the public body Network Rail, which manages the track at the moment and will be absorbed into GBR.  Passenger numbers have soared since train operation was privatised in the mid-s, but there’s been a deluge of complaints about quality and cost. The review was triggered by those complaints and the chaotic introduction of new timetables in May , which exposed “no one in charge” of the network. Rail franchises were then effectively ended when the Government took over the financial risks of operators in March  to keep services running due to Covid. But this is not an end to privatisation. GBR will award contracts to private firms to run trains, with incentives based on performance and passenger numbers. Will it actually make my tickets cheaper  Ah. Here’s the tricky part. No, not exactly. There has been no commitment for an overall reduction in fares. And indeed, Grant Shapps refused to promise they’ll rise by inflation or less in future years. Instead, the Government has pledged to simply the fares system and offer digital ticketing and more flexibility. In theory, that will make things cheaper , say, you were bamboozled by the system and got ripped off before. But overall, it’s very woolly. Mr Shapps warned railways are already subsidised and taxpayers plugged a £bn Covid hole. He also warned “there’ll be no instant changes” to fare prices and this will be a “multi-year change”. And today’s report says: “It is not possible to continue paying revenue support inde nitely on the present scale, around four times the amount provided before the pandemic.” The new contracts will have a string of requirements on train firms - including punctuality, reliability, passenger satisfaction, capacity, staff availability and helpfulness, customer information, vandalism repair, passenger satisfaction, “revenue protection” and cleanliness.Not a single one of those requirements is to actually make the fares cheaper.  OK, so how *might* it make fares cheaper  If you’re feeling generous, you’d say the overall reforms to simply the system might make things cheaper in the long run. It’s claimed the overall reforms could save £.bn a year after five years - equal to % of all income from fares. Reforms including ditching the legal departments arguing over what sized bird hit a power cable and therefore who’s responsible. But there’s no suggestion this cost saving will be passed on to passengers via a cut in ticket prices.  Meanwhile, the report says: “On long-distance services, where operators will have more commercial freedom, including more control over fare setting, a greater range of book-ahead tickets will be offered. “These will help to end the sudden clfs in prices that passengers can encounter at dferent times of day.” It also says the dference between peak and off-peak could reduce. “If commuter demand permanently and signi cantly reduces, some of the assumptions around the peak timetable and charging structure may change.” And how might it *not* make fares cheaper  The report explicitly says some firms will be allowed to “act more commercially” on some services as passenger numbers tick up. “Operators on those routes, predominantly the long-distance ones, will be able to make more decisions including setting more of their own fares and taking more revenue risk,” it says. The report says “affordable walk-up fares” will be preserved “as now”. But many passengers faced with eye-watering on the day costs will claim this is nonsense, and they should be cheaper than they are now.  What is the one instant change to fares  New flexible season tickets will be introduced from June , ready for use from June . They can be used for travel on any eight days in a -day period - making things cheaper for commuters who go in for two to three days per week. The Department for Transport claims this will save part-time commuters hundreds of pounds per year compared with buying daily tickets. What other changes to tickets will there be  There will also be a signicant rollout of more pay-as-you-go, contactless and digital ticketing on smartphones, the Department for Transportsaid. More areas will have contactless pay-as-you-go ticketing like London’s Oyster card, which takes payments out of a balance using fare zones. And anywhere in the country you should be able to use a digital ticket on a smartphone app. Private firms will be able to combine rail travel with other services such as hiring bikes, booking hotel rooms or experiences like sports and concert tickets.Rather than making fares cheaper, this could make them easier to use and navigate - and to get the cheapest fare on offer. The announcement that GBR will sell tickets led to shares in retailer Trainline plunging by more than % in early trading, wiping around £ million off its value. Will the new system make my train run on time  There will be incentives to do so - but nothing’s guaranteed. The Government believes scrapping the franchise system will lead to operators being more focused on improving services. The new concession model is similar to the one successfully used by Transport for London for its London Overground and Docklands Light Railway networks. Ministers also hope there will be a smoother link in the management of train and track. When will I actually see a dference  Not soon. “I can’t pretend that suddenly instantly just because we’re changing the name the trains will run on time,” Mr Shapps admitted. It’s already taken years for this plan to be agreed, and GBR is not expected to be established until . Passenger watchdog Transport Focus said passengers will welcome this move towards a more accountable and joined up railway. But the announcement was criticised by trade unions, with the Transport Salaried Staffsapos Association describing it as an attempt merely to paper over the cracks. Labour’s Shadow Transport Secretary Jim McMahon said: “Nearly three years after it was commissioned, this report raises more questions than it answers. “With fare hikes, £ billion cuts to Network Rail and broken promises to communities across the country, it’s yet another example of ministers talking a good game, with very little substance underneath.”FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnGrant ShappsDepartment for TransportAppsRailwaysSmartphones

story: NewsMenopausal woman who lost two children and miscarried twice welcomes baby at EXCLUSIVE: Karen Seaton and her partner Rich suffered their fair share of tragedy in trying to conceive, but just as they were about to give up hope, they received the most wonderful surprisemirrorShareCommentsByJessica Taylor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsKaren Seaton has opened up about raising a toddler while going through menopause" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeKaren Seaton and her partner Rich were beginning to lose all hope of having their own kids. At , Karen had three sons from another relationship and Rich adored them. But the pair felt they had room for one more in their brood. However, after falling pregnant twice and miscarrying both times, Karen’s mental health was suffering. “It was horrendous. I lost both pregnancies fairly late and Rich and I were struggling,” Karen, now , told The Mirror. The miscarriages brought back painful memories for Karen, who had already suffered the loss of two daughters when she was in her s and with her first husband. Mari, her first daughter, suffered complications in the womb and didn’t survive childbirth. A few years later Georgia came along, but she tragically died at four and a half months old.  Just  at the time, Karen was devastated to learn she and her husband couldn’t conceive successfully after post-mortems revealed both girls had a genetic heart condition. Both desperate for a family, the couple amicably parted ways. “We’re still friends today. We went through so much together and will always have that bond,” Karen says. In time, she remarried and had three sons George, Harry and Archie. After Archie was born, Karen’s  year marriage broke down and she became a single mum, with the boys visiting their dad on weekends. “It was absolute chaos in my household,” she joked. “I was barely ever in the house for all the running around I did!” Then, seven years ago, she connected with an old family friend, Rich. “I’d known Rich since we were kids but we’d lost touch. After his marriage ended we got back in touch and ended up in a relationship,” she explained.  “I thought I was done with kids - in fact, they weren’t even on my radar, but Rich didn’t have any children of his own. “I decided: ‘Let’s try and see what happens’.” To Karen’s surprise, she fell pregnant in her s. But things weren’t to be, and the pair were heartbroken to discover she’d miscarried. After picking themselves up to try again, they were dealt another blow with a second miscarriage. “I put it down to my age, but we were really low,” she described. “It was starting to affect our relationship. “By now I was  and losing hope. I decided to set myself a deadline for my th birthday. If I wasn’t pregnant by then, it wasn’t going to happen for us.” After the final month of trying, Karen bought a pregnancy test. When it came back positive, she was stunned. But instead of worrying about another miscarriage, a wave of calm washed over her. “I just had this gut feeling everything would work out this time,” she told The Mirror. But despite feeling cool about the pregnancy, Karen was less laid back about telling the boys her news.  “I didn’t know how they’d react. We put some scan photos into envelopes for them to open and waited for their reaction.” Luckily, the boys were thrilled at the idea of having a little sister. After a visit to her GP, Karen was prescribed hormone medication to help the pregnancy go as smoothly as possible, as she’d had her thyroid removed a few years earlier. In time, miracle baby Mia was born and Karen’s brood was complete. After a one month stay in hospital for a respiratory condition, Mia recovered fully and thrived with three big brothers to dote on her. “I was a dferent mum the second time around. I was so much more chilled out,” she said, citing breastfeeding as an example. “Mia was being fed through a tube for the first month of her le so once she was out of hospital, it made more sense to bottle feed her. “I breastfed all the boys and I know I’d have been upsetI couldn’t do that. But with Mia, I was older and more experienced, so I knew she had to be fed and that was the most important thing.” In between juggling kids and work with handling menopause symptoms, Karen also finds time to run an Instagram page, @tryingmybestoldermumma and write a blog.Karen told The Mirror: “I started the Instagram page because I realised there weren’t many voices of older mums out there. “Since starting it up, I’ve had so many older mums reach out to thank me for being open with my story.” One issue Karen touches on through her Instagram page is raising a toddler while going through menopause, which started when she was  and Mia was two. “I can’t tellmy exhaustion is normal from raising a child ormenopause is a factor,” she said. “I’m lucky in that I’ve not had mood swings, but I get hot flushes and night sweats. “I also have brain fog sometimes so I have to make to-do lists every day!” Mia is now three years old and is doing well. “She’s such a good child. She sleeps through the night and she’s so happy all the time,” Karen gushed. Big brothers George, Harry and Archie are now ,  and , and they’re incredibly protective of their baby sister. “They absolutely adore her,” Karen said, adding that their dad even buys gts for Mia at Christmas. There have been times when Karen has worried about her age, but she brushes off any doubts. “I am very aware that I’m the oldest mum on the school run and sometimes I worry that Mia might get teased for having an older mum. I also wish my energy levels were a bit higher to run around after her. “But Mia is a blessing and I’m so lucky to have her. I feel like I’ve got my happy ending.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnBabiesPregnancyMiscarriageMenopause

Scots student Kieran Munns said he is recovering after the horror attack in Northern Zululand, South Africa on Wednesday. The -year-old, whose family are from Livingston, has been studying in the country for the past two years at Bhejane Nature Training, and had hoped to join a special team protecting the beasts.Kieran was carrying out a foot patrol when the animal charged at him and he somehow emerged without serious injuries, he told the Daily Record.The student said he suffered a bang on the head after one of the massive animals attacked and was then trampled on by the mother rhinoaposs young calf.  A search and rescue operation was launched and paramedics rushed Kieran to hospital - but he has vowed to never stop helping animals in need. Speaking from his hospital bed in Africa, Kieran described how he would continue in his conservation efforts and held no grudges against rhinos after the incident. He said: I have been studying in South Africa for almost two years and had the opportunity to be part of the rhino monitoring team for the morning.  This is an important part of rhino conservation for which I am passionate and want to be heavily involved. Itaposs true that unfortunately the encounter turned ugly due [to] unfortunate but uncontrollable circumstances and was I injured. But nothing more than a bang to the head from falling from the mother and my hip getting injured by being stepped on by a young calf which was with the mother black rhino. No serious injuries have occurred. Iaposm not fighting for my le, no surgery is needed and Iaposm making a rapid recovery. I absolutely love what I do and have no negative feelings towards the innocent and how it was dealt with, I still love and adore all animals including black rhino and look forward to being back in the field as soon as Iaposm able. My colleagues have been exceptional.  He added: Of course itaposs scary in the moment, but I have no negative thoughts about the whole incident and super keen to get back out there. A post on social media from the IPSS medical rescue service said that he was being treated at Zulu-Natal hospital. Analysis has show seven of the UKaposs biggest  travel firms are offering trips to amber list countries, as well as budget airlines Ryanair and easyJet, seemingly in the face of government advice. Some companies have slashed prices by half and Ryanair is offering plane tickets for as little as £ in a bid to get business moving again after a torrid year of lockdowns and travel bans. Holiday favourites Spain, Greece, Italy and France are all currently on the governmentaposs amber list of destinations, meaning holidaymakers must quarantine for  days on ing and take two pricey Covid tests. EasyJet and Ryanair have confirmed that seats are selling, but Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has told people not to travel - while refusing to actually ban trips to amber list countries. The mixed messages have left Brits with holidays already booked facing losing hundreds of poundsthey cannot isolate for  days afterwards. Some firms are refusing refunds or charging large rebooking fees for trips to non-red list countries.How have your holiday plans been affected  Email webnews@mirror One nurse claimed she was £ out of pocket having had to change the dates of Ryanair flights to an amber list country because she couldnapost get time off work to self-isolate. Last night Ryanair CEO Michael OaposLeary said that people had been booking in their droves for the past four weeks. The budget airline launched a flash sale yesterday running to midnight tonight with dozens of flights on offer for just £. While the list of cut price destinations including Bologna, Barcelona and Bratislava may be tempting, the price of testing before and after the getaway bumps the cost up by several hundred pounds per person. Big deals are also up for grabs through easyJet, where the companies low-fare finder tool offers summer getaways to a whole host of destinations not on the green list. For just £. Brits can fly from London Gatwick to Agadir in Morocco this August, or from Bristol to Bodrum, Turkey for £.. EasyJet has not launched any specic promotions to amber list destinations but regular flights are available. When askedeasyJet customers were flying to amber countries for leisure despite Government guidance, easyJet chief executive Johan Lundgren replied: Yes, people are booking flights and theyaposre going there on holidays.  Package holiday firms are also getting in on the action after months of business-stling travel bans. Tui has a host of deals including a trip to the Blue Lagoon Resort in Kos, Greece for seven nights at the beginning of June. The travel behemoth has slashed the sticker price from £, to £ per person. You could also spend a week in the sparkling blue waters of Fuerteventura, Spain where an all inclusive stay at TUI MAGIC LIFE is down to £ from £. Unlike easyJet and Ryanair however, Tui has stopped all trips to red and amber list countries until June , when a review of the countries by the government is due. According to Which , seven of the ten biggest holiday companies are flogging holidays to amber list countries this month or in early June.  They were TUI, easyJet Holidays, British Airways Holidays, Expedia, Lastminute, Virgin and Travel Republic. The hot deals on offer to amber list countries highlight a problem at the centre of the governmentaposs traffic light system, which came into force on Monday. Only  countries are on the green list, while most of Europe is amber - meaning passengers arriving back in the UK are required to self-isolate for  days and take two expensive Covid tests. Rather than ban trips to amber countries altogether, the government has simply pleaded with people to only make the journeysthey need to. All the while cheap flights to sun doused beaches and bargain package holidays are being sold, with as many as ,, people expected to fly out of the UK to amber list countries by Sunday. Yesterday Matt Hancock, Health Secretary, told the Commons that government advice was very clear - that people should not travel to amber or red-list countries or territories...for a holiday. Unfortunately he was undermined by Environment Secretary George Eustice, who said the amber destinations were for people who wanted to visit family or friends. Prime Minister Boris Johnson later claried that countries in the category should only be visited for some extreme circumstance, such as the serious illness of a family member.Such mixed messaging was no good for the thousands of Brits with holidays booked to amber countries who now face signicant losses however. Those heading to red list destinations are entitled to a full refund because the travel firm will be forced to cancel. The same is not true for amber list countries, eventhe tripaposs purpose flies in the face of one or more of the many bits of the governmentaposs advice. Tracey Godfrey is one of those people out of pocket. I booked through a travel agent and have cancelled my holiday due to it being on the amber list, cannot travel for leisure purposes, she tweeted at Ryanair.  I tried to change the dates of the holiday but you are charging £ flight operator fees. I booked this holiday in June . Another woman, who works as a nurse, said the airline was asking for £ to change flights to Majorca - something she may be forced to do due to being unable to isolate for ten days because of her work. Lisa Tones was in a similar position, explaining: I’m wanting to change my flights from June  to June  to Rome. I’m not wanting to cancel just move the date, so why am I being asked to pay another £ to do this when Rome is still in amber  Shocking. That was what happened to Ekow Otoo – an actor, spoken-word poet and model. “My legs had been giving me problems for years I was suffering a relapse and felt too weak to cook, so I’d ordered a takeaway. I remember being pinned to the wall when I took the pizzas from the delivery guy – they were too heavy to walk with,” says Ghanian-born Londoner Ekow, now . Ekow, who now knows he has multiple sclerosis , started experiencing issues aged . “I tried to get out of my bed one morning and my legs wouldn’t follow. After a nap they were fine again, but next time I played basketball I couldn’t run – my knees would buckle and I couldn’t get any speed.” A GP put the issue down to Ekow shooting up six inches in just one year. “They just thought I’d grown too quickly and my muscles were catching up.” MS is an inflammatory disease in which the nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord are damaged. Slowly the disease affected Ekow to the point he had to give up sport entirely. “I couldn’t even walk two roads without resting on walls.” At university Ekow struggled to get information from his brain to the page. “I think they thought I was lazy,” he says. “I didn’t connect the problem with my legs, though.”  Help and advice In February , Ekow went to bed with a chest infection. “When I woke I felt funny, sat down and couldn’t stand up again. I ended up in hospital with a doctor standing over my bed, saying: ‘This is MS.’ I remember thinking, ‘Wow, there’s a name for it.’ “It was such a relief to have a definitive diagnosis. I knew it wasn’t all in my head.” When he was first given his wheelchair, Ekow was, “overcome with peace”: “I thought it was going to be a massive struggle, but I sat in the chair and pushed for the first time, and it was like all the stress melted away. “It turns out I’m really good at it. The UKaposs vaccine rollout is not complete, so we donapost know the full picture yet while the jabs are only now getting to younger adults. But there are two sets of official data that can help give us some clues about the scale of vaccine hesitancy right now. It is important to note some people reject or delay vaccines for health reasons on the advice of their doctors - for instance, because they are immunocompromised. The Office for National Statisticsis tracking vaccine uptake in two ways - looking at the numbers who have turned down a jab already, and surveying peopleaposs attitudes.  Because elderly and vulnerable people were first in the jabs queue, the ONS data measuring actual vaccine uptake rates currently only covers over-s.It found .% of all residents in England aged  years and over had received at least one dose. And the most recent ONS survey on hesitancy suggests positive vaccine sentiment among people in the UK surveyed had actually increased to % in the latest period .Thataposs up from % when the figures were first collected in December.Who is rejecting Covid vaccines Again, itaposs really too soon to know for sure as the rollout to younger adults gets underway. Because so few young people have been vaccinated, the full scale of rejection is not known. The ONS vaccine surveys give some idea of which groups are most likely to decline the Covid shots on offer. The highest levels of Covid vaccine hesitancy are seen among younger adults, who the rollout is yet to extend to. Four in ten black adults were most likely to report vaccine hesitancy earlier this year, but the latest data showed that had shrunk to around  in  by March. In Bolton, an expert gave another explanation this week for why some people might not be taking up the jab in poorer areas - explaining itaposs not just about fear.Dr Helen Wall, senior responsible officer for the vaccination programme in Bolton, told the Manchester Evening News failure to get a jab could be down in part to deprivation.I donapost think thereaposs a hesitancy as such, I think itaposs more about the barriers to vaccination, she said. In response to those concerns, Boltonaposs NHS launched a aposvaccine busapos for communities with the lowest uptake.Are anti-vaxxers affecting uptake rates  The UK is already facing anti-vaccine sentiment, and jab conspiracy theories have been pushed at anti-lockdown rallies throughout the past year. Some experts have blamed it the spread of vaccine denial myths on social media, which long predate the pandemic. In March , the NHS England chief executive of NHS England warned anti-vaxxers influencing people on social media may be contributing to the declining uptake of the childhood MMR measles jab.
